items.message: River levels are rising on the River Rye catchment due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include land around the River Rye and it's tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck, Spittle Beck, including properties of Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please monitor local weather and river conditions and avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Seven catchment due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include land around the River Seven and it's tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck, Catter Beck, including properties in Sinnington and to the East of Normanby. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please monitor local weather and river conditions and avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to recent rainfall.

Areas most at risk include the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible in these areas.

Further light rainfall is forecast throughout  the week.

The Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and Lake Windermere will remain high today, but we do not expect any flooding to properties.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Newby Bridge sluices remain open due to high lake levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Lake levels on Derwent Water and river levels in Borrowdale remain high due to recent rainfall.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and low lying areas in Borrowdale.

River and lake levels are expected to remain high throughout the week.

Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the week.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Lake levels on Derwent Water remain high due to recent rainfall.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.

Lake levels are expected to remain high throughout the week.

Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the week keeping lake levels high at the Lodore gauge.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected along riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith and South Esplanade.  Levels have now peaked and we expect them to continue to fall slowly today, Tuesday 21/11/2023. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk include local roads and low-lying land around Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. Levels are expected to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please monitor local weather and river conditions and avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling, on the River Thame as a result of previous heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 21/11/23, especially in the Thame, Stadhampton, and Dorchester areas. The outlook is mainly dry today, 21/11/23, and for the coming days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 22/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
The forecast is for drier weather for this coming week, although showers are still possible for today, Monday 20/11/2023.
The Washford River remains high but is falling and is not expected to rise again over the next few days. There may remain some limited flooding of low-lying land and roads in and around the Washford River. The Horner Water, River Aller, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream and Doniford Stream are now back to normal winter base flow levels. We expect to remove this Flood Warning later today or on Tuesday.
Please consider the weather conditions and local water levels and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor the river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens.
This message will be updated by 11am on 21/11/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: This flood alert has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern. There is further rain forecast for the next few days and we will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham
items.message: River levels remain high but are slowly falling on Broadlane Beck and Creyke Beck due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include properties around King Street, Northgate, Dunswell Road and North Moor Lane. This means properties are at risk of flooding. We expect levels to remain high today, Tuesday 21/11/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull

items.message: River levels remain high in the Cottingham area due to recent rainfall. The areas most at risk include Cottingham, Kirk Ella, Anlaby and Hessle. Levels are steady, however, we expect levels to remain high today, Tuesday 21/11/23. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated at 8pm on 21/11/23 or as the situation changes.

The flood risk has now decreased but water still remains on Curry Moor and Hay Moor and we will continue to pump water to reduce levels further. For information, the River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.15m and the drain level at Currymoor is 5.37m. The forecast is for drier weather for this coming week, although showers are still possible for today, Monday 20/11/2023. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

River levels have risen slowly at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of rainfall over weekend.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Actual peak:- Llanymynech 4.0 m overnight Sunday.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. However, some scattered showers may be possible on Thursday.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.   

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 22/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued by the Environment Agency. 

Flood Alert in force: Lower Avon and tributaries. 

Flooding is possible for: Tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.    

Be prepared.

 River levels are high but steady at the Ringwood Old Cottage river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated Wednesday, 22/11/23, or as the situation changes. 

To check the latest information for your area

items.message:
Levels are slowly rising on the Dee due to recent rainfall.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are slowly falling on the River Blackwater and The Cove Brook. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing. It is forecast to be mostly dry today 21/11/23, with outbreaks of light rain at times. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening 21/11/23 or if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels have fallen following recent rainfall but levels in York remain high. Areas most at risk include the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas.  Levels have now peaked in York and we expect them to continue to fall slowly today, Tuesday 21/11/2023. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Monday 20th November 2023. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas on the Deben from Debenham to Ufford, including Framsden, Earl Soham, Easton, Glevering and Wickham Market, and on the Rivers Lark and Finn around Witnesham, Tuddenham St Martin, Playford and Grundisburgh. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for scattered showers for the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Tuesday 21st November, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high and steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall during the past week.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.    

No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. However, some scattered showers may be possible on Thursday.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.   

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 22/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Monday 20th November. Water levels continue to remain high in this area. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent high rainfall across the area. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. The forecast for today is for scattered showers, Monday 20th November. Further scattered showers are also forecast for the next few days. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Tuesday 21st November, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are now falling on the Bristol Avon at Bradford-on-Avon and the Semington Brook at Semington. Little rain has fallen in the 24 hours and the forecast shows a number of dry days ahead from today, the 21st November 2023. We expect this Flood Alert to be removed today or tomorrow.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, or sooner if the situation changes

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rain or drizzle is forecast over the next few days.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Crew Green river gauge. It will become more settled and drier for the remainder of the week. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. Actual Peaks:- Crew Green 5.53m Monday evening, Montford currently peaking at 4.6m, Predicted Peaks:- Welshbridge 2.3m to 2.4m Tuesday afternoon, 21/11/2023, Buildwas 3.3m to 3.4m Tuesday evening, 21/11/2023.  

We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days. However, some scattered showers may be possible on Thursday.  
 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.   
This message will be updated by 10:00am on 22/11/23, or as the situation changes.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Water levels in the Eastern Yar are still high. A small amount of rain (5mm) has been recorded at Knighton today (Monday 20/11/2023). At Alverstone and Langbridge, the river may rise slightly before falling at around 17:00 today (20/11/2023). No further impacts are expected. At Sandown, the level will remain high for longer where minor impacts associated with waterlogged ditches will be experienced. This Flood Alert will remain in force until the river level measured at Sandown has fallen to 1.07mAOD and minor impacts are no longer expected. We will continue to manage the water level at Bembridge and monitor the forecast. This message will be updated by 15:00 on 21/11/2023.

items.description: Slad Brook from Upper Steanbridge Mill to Rowcroft, Stroud
items.message:
River levels are high but steady as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and adjacent land is expected in the next few hours.  We expect flooding to affect Flood Warning for The Vatch - fast flowing increased water levels may impact properties in The Vatch. Install Property level protection if required. Monitor the brook for further increases   
Consequently flooding could occur in the next few hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and or Local Authorities.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in York in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect riverside properties, properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Levels in York at the Viking recorder are currently around 3m. Levels have now peaked and we expect them to continue to fall slowly today, Tuesday 21/11/2023. The Foss Barrier is in operation. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

A band of rain is expected this morning 20/11/23, with isolated showers throughout the day and overnight. The outlook for the rest of the week has improved. The Aldingbourne Rife remains high but is slowly falling. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, some areas of Durban Road, fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, as well as caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The Barnham Rife is also slowly falling. Flood impacts could continue in Bersted. Some light showers are forecast for Tuesday (21/11/2023). Wednesday (22/11/2023) and Thursday (23/11/2023) are expected to remain dry. Water levels should start to reduce but will remain higher than normal until at least the weekend. The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 on 22/11/2023.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station (HEPS) is 8.01 m and is currently stable. The drain level at HEPS is 7.72 m and is slowly falling.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m.
The forecast is for much drier weather for this coming week, although showers are still possible for the remainder of Monday and early Tuesday morning. 
When river levels allow, pumping continues at Huish Episcopi and we are utilising the Parrett Relief Channel to evacuate water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. This message will be updated by 11am on Tuesday 21/11/2023.
Please consider local water levels and weather conditions and do not walk or drive through flood water.
For water levels on the River Yeo and the drain at HEPS please refer to our website: (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
The forecast is for drier weather for this coming week, although showers are still possible for the remainder of Monday and early Tuesday morning. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This Flood Alert remains in force due to the flooding of large areas of the Somerset Levels and Moors and flood water continues to affect the Langport to Muchelney Road.
We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. This message will be updated by 1 pm on Tuesday 21/11/2023.

River levels are still rising slowly on the River Derwent due to rainfall over the weekend. Flooding remains a risk near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Buttercrambe Mill at Buttercrambe Bridge. Further showers are forecast and we expect expect levels to remain high overnight into tomorrow, Tuesday 21/11/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Lower Dorset Frome due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Derwent at Stamford Bridge - The Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent due to rainfall over the weekend. The area most at risk is around River Derwent at Stamford Bridge - The Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge. We expect levels to remain high today, Tuesday 21/11/23. Please consider putting your flood plan into action and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message by 8pm on 21/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels are falling but still remain high at Frodingham Beck and on the River Hull due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include the upper Hull area including Kilham, Nafferton, Driffield, Bainton, North Dalton, Leconfield, Leven, Brandesburton, North Frodingham and Beeford. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today, Tuesday 20/11/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 21/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are remaining high on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, River Nadder.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, River Nadder, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood.
Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow morning.
River levels are remaining high.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: River Thames for Henley, Remenham, Medmenham and its tributaries

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Oxfordshire, Windsor and Maidenhead, Wokingham
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Assendon Stream, Hambledon Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  

Scattered showers are forecast this evening and overnight 20/11/23. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. We have been checking the condition of defences and clearing debris from weed screens.  

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
The very gradual rise in groundwater levels over the last few days will turn into a gentle recession over the next ten days or so, as dryer weather brought about by high pressure becomes more dominant. Groundwater levels across West Dorset will, however, remain exceptionally high for this point in the season. Consequently any periods of extended heavy rainfall will see a quick return to flood conditions.  Some flooding of minor roads is still causing local problems, though levels have fallen back considerably. Avoid driving through flood water wherever possible.
 Environment Agency staff will continue to monitor groundwater conditions daily and this Alert will be reissued should our forecast models predict that flood thresholds will be crossed once more.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have remained high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days. Groundwater levels in the area are currently stable but remain responsive to rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain.

Groundwater level will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 25/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Piddle.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham from 09:00 AM on 18/11/2023.
Further light rainfall is forecast this afternoon.
River levels are high but steady, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
The very gradual rise in groundwater levels over the last few days will turn into a gentle recession over the next ten days or so, as dryer weather brought about by high pressure becomes more dominant. Groundwater levels across Cranborne Chase will, however, remain exceptionally high for this point in the season. Consequently any periods of extended heavy rainfall will see a quick return to flood conditions.  Some flooding of minor roads is still causing local problems, though levels have fallen back considerably. Avoid driving through flood water wherever possible.
 Environment Agency staff will continue to monitor groundwater conditions daily and this Alert will be reissued should our forecast models predict that flood thresholds will be crossed once more.

The River Lavant remains high but is slowly falling. Minimal flood impacts are expected which could affect fields, rural roads and gardens between West Dean and Westhampnett. In East Lavant, water may affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green, and possibly access bridges over the river. Flood water could affect gardens and approach properties at The Sadlers, Westhampnett. Some light showers are forecast for Tuesday (21/11/2023). Wednesday (22/11/2023) and Thursday (23/11/2023) are expected to remain dry. Water levels should start to reduce, but will remain higher than normal until at least Thursday (23/11/2023). Some roads could be affected by flood water. Plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Sheepwash Lane. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are managing structures in Westhampnett to reduce flood risk on the River Lavant. We will update this message by 11:00 on 22/11/2023.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the River Leach. Therefore, the risk of further flooding of low lying land is reducing. The outlook is mainly dry today, 21/11/23, and for the coming days. River levels are falling and we expect this to continue. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 22/11/23, or as the situation changes.
This flood warning has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern. There is further rain forecast over the next few days and we will reissue this warning if necessary.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  

Scattered showers are forecast this evening and overnight 20/11/23. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. We have been checking the condition of defences and clearing debris from weed screens.  

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.
